courses.name: General Economics
courses.description: One semester course covering similar material as covered in ECONOM 1014 and  ECONOM 1015.  Topics include opportunity costs, gains from trade, efficiency and markets, non-competitive markets, game theory, government spending and taxation, economic growth, monetary and fiscal policy, unemployment and inflation, exchange rates.  Includes applications for Journalism students.  Not open to students who have completed ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024 and, ECONOM 1015 or AG_EC 1041 and AG_EC 1042.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Open only to pre-Journalism and Journalism majors; departmental consent required

courses.name: Principles of Microeconomics
courses.description: A basic examination of the economy at the individual consumer, firm and market level.  Simple economic models used to analyze the workings of the economy.  Topics include opportunity costs, gains from trade, efficiency and markets, non-competitive markets, game theory, the importance of free trade, the markets response to economic shocks and the effect of government intervention.  Not open to students who have completed ECONOM 1024, ECONOM 1051, or AG_EC 1041.

courses.name: Principles of Macroeconomics
courses.description: Macroeconomics generally refers to a collection of questions about how scarcity affects a collection of people interacting with one another.  In this course, our focus is on understanding how scarcity affects welfare of a nation.  Topics include Gross Domestic Product, government spending and taxation, economic growth, monetary and fiscal policy, unemployment and inflation, and exchange rates.  Not open to students who have completed ECONOM 1051 or AG_EC 1042.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Microeconomics
courses.description: This course uses mathematical reasoning to provide an elementary quantitative introduction to fundamental concepts in microeconomics.  It uses college algebra and simple geometric concepts to describe the behavior of economic units, such as consumers, firms and resource owners, and to depict their interaction through production and exchange in perfect and imperfect markets.  Not open to students who have completed ECONOM 1014, ECONOM 1051, or AG_EC 1041. Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1100 or MATH 1120 or equivalent with grade of C or better

courses.name: General Economics - Honors
courses.description: One semester course covering similar material as covered in ECONOM 1014 and ECONOM 1015.  Topics include opportunity costs, gains from trade, efficiency and markets, non-competitive markets, game theory, government spending and taxation, economic growth, monetary and fiscal policy, unemployment and inflation, exchange rates.  Not open to students who have completed ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024 and ECONOM 1015. Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.

courses.name: Undergraduate Topics in Economics - Social Science
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in Economics; applied or theoretical economics; covers subjects not included in regularly offered courses.

courses.name: Topics in Economics - Social Science
courses.description: Study in applied or theoretical economics; covers subjects not included in regularly offered courses.

courses.name: Introduction to International Economics
courses.description: A topical course which emphasizes the application of basic economic analysis to real and current international economic issues. Topics include free trade, protectionism, free trade areas, multilateral trade negotiations, trade and development, exchange rates, the International Monetary System, and economic integration.

courses.name: Money, Banking and Financial Markets
courses.description: Operation of the U.S. financial and economic system. Covers interest rates, banking regulation, the money supply process and the conduct of the Federal Reserve, inflation and the macroeconomy, exchange rates and the international financial system, rational expectations, and efficient markets.
courses.prerequisites: (ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024) and ECONOM 1015, or ECONOM 1051, or AG ECON 1041 with a minimum grade of C-

courses.name: Money, Banking and Financial Markets - Honors
courses.description: Operation of the U.S. financial and economic system. Covers interest rates, banking regulation, the money supply process and the conduct of the Federal Reserve, inflation and the macroeconomy, exchange rates and the international financial system, rational expectations, and efficient markets.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024 and ECONOM 1015, or ECONOM 1051. Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Theory of the Firm
courses.description: Theory of rational behavior in consumption, production, and pricing decisions of households and firms.  Topics include the economics of the firm in the context of partial equilibria in product and factor markets under competition, monopoly, oligopoly and monopolistic competition as well as game theory. No credit for students who have completed ECONOM 4351.
courses.prerequisites: (ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024 or ECONOM 1051) and MATH 1400, or equivalent.  Not open to economics majors

courses.name: Introduction to Applied Econometric Practice
courses.description: Introduction to the use of regression analysis of economic data, including simple and multiple regression, dummy variables. Econometric problems considered include heteroscedasticity, autocorrelation, multicollinearity and simultaneous equation issues.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024 and ECONOM 1015, or ECONOM 1051H and STAT 2500

courses.name: Capitalism, Democracy and Society
courses.description: This is a one-credit seminar course for students interested in careers involving social science research and analysis; topics covered will be a selection of classic and contemporary debates in the social sciences.

courses.name: Internship
courses.description: Internship experience for students interested in economics. Supervised internship work with approval of Director of Undergraduate Studies and academic adviser. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Practicum in Economics
courses.description: Practical experience in consulting, teaching or research guided by faculty advisor. Graded on S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: consent of Director of Undergraduate Studies and faculty advisor
courses.recommendation: Grade of B or higher in ECONOM 4351 and ECONOM 4371

courses.name: Topics in Economics- Social Science
courses.description: Study in applied or theoretical economics; covers subjects not included in regularly offered courses.

courses.name: Topics in Economics- Social Science - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Study in applied or theoretical economics; covers subjects not included in regularly offered courses.

courses.name: Labor Economics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7311). Surveys theoretical explanations of wage and employment determination in contemporary labor markets.

courses.name: Labor Economics - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Surveys theoretical explanations of wage and employment determination in contemporary labor markets.

courses.name: Public Economics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4315). Analyzes economic effects of government expenditures, taxes and debt. Expenditure and taxation principles, tax reform, cost-benefit analysis, fiscal policy.

courses.name: Public Economics - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Analyzes economic effects of government expenditures, taxes and debt. Expenditure and taxation principles, tax reform, cost-benefit analysis, fiscal policy.

courses.name: History of Economic Thought
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7320). Origins of modern economic thought in the context of social and intellectual environment of the time in which they originated, their contribution to their period and to modern thought.
courses.prerequisites: (ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024) and ECONOM 1015, or ECONOM 1051

courses.name: History of Economic Thought
courses.description: Origins of modern economic thought in the context of social and intellectual environment of the time in which they originated, their contribution to their period and to modern thought.
courses.prerequisites: (ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024) and ECONOM 1015, or ECONOM 1051

courses.name: Economics of Regulation and Antitrust
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7322Economic issues concerning the role of government regulation. The course examines the rationale for and effects of regulatory policies in public utilities, transportation, and communications industries.

courses.name: The International Monetary System
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7325). Study of macroeconomic and monetary relationships between the U.S. and the world. Topics include balance of payments, foreign exchange rates, history of the international monetary system.

courses.name: Economics of International Trade
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7326). The microeconomic theory of international trade. Topics include comparative advantage, the theory of commercial policy, economic integration, trade with less developed countries and the trade effects of economic growth.

courses.name: The Banking System and the Money Market
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7329). Organization of the money market; credit control procedures and aims, effect of bank expansion and contraction on money market and national income deregulation.

courses.name: The Banking System and the Money Market - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Organization of the money market; credit control procedures and aims, effect of bank expansion and contraction on money market and national income deregulation.

courses.name: Introduction to Game Theory
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7340). An introduction to the theory of games, viewed as a set of tools used widely in economics to study situations in which decision-makers (consumers, firms, governments, etc.) interact. The course introduces the basic theory, emphasizing the concepts and their economic applications.

courses.name: Economics of Education
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7345). Economic theory is used to analyze the market for educational services and education policy. Topics include: human capital theory, cost and performance measures for public and private schools, market based approaches to school reform, school finance, higher education cost and access.
courses.prerequisites: (ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024 or ECONOM 1051), and STAT 2500 or equivalent

courses.name: Economics of Education - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Economic theory is used to analyze the market for educational services and education policy. Topics include: human capital theory, cost and performance measures for public and private schools, market based approaches to school reform, school finance, higher education cost and access.
courses.prerequisites: (ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024 or ECONOM 1051), and STAT 2500 or equivalent

courses.name: Intermediate Microeconomics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7351). Theory of rational behavior in consumption, production, and pricing decisions of households and firms. Partial equilibria in product and factor markets under competition, monopoly, oligopoly and monopolistic competition. A brief introduction to general equilibrium and welfare economics is provided. Calculus is employed. No credit for students who have completed ECONOM 3251.
courses.prerequisites: (ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024 or ECONOM 1051) and MATH 1400 or equivalent

courses.name: Intermediate Microeconomics - Honors
courses.description: Theory of rational behavior in consumption, production, and pricing decisions of households and firms. Partial equilibria in product and factor markets under competition, monopoly, oligopoly and monopolistic competition. A brief introduction to general equilibrium and welfare economics is provided. Calculus is employed. No credit for students who have completed ECONOM 3251.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024 or ECONOM 1051, and MATH 1400, or equivalent. Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Intermediate Macroeconomics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7353). The study of the structure and performance of national economics.  Topics include: long-term economic growth, aggregate economic fluctuations, unemployment, and inflation; consequences for national economies of being part of the global economic system; government policies and macroeconomic performance.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 1015 or ECONOM 1051, and MATH 1400 or equivalent

courses.name: Industrial Organization and Competitive Strategy
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7355). Analyzes the structure of industry, its impact on the operations of the firm and significance for public policy.  The focus is on strategic interaction among firms with market power.  Topics include oligopoly, competition, collusion, price discrimination, product differentiation, advertising, entry and exit.

courses.name: Industrial Organization and Competitive Strategy - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Analyzes the structure of industry, its impact on the operations of the firm and significance for public policy.  The focus is on strategic interaction among firms with market power.  Topics include oligopoly, competition, collusion, price discrimination, product differentiation, advertising, entry and exit.

courses.name: Health Economics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4357, PUB_AF 4357). Analyzes the economics of health care in the United States with particular attention paid to the role of government.  It examines the demand for health care and the structure and consequences of public and private health insurance; the supply of health care, including professional training, licensure, specialization and compensation, hospital competition and finance, and the determinants and consequences of technical change in medicine and health care reform.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 3251 or ECONOM 4351 and STAT 2500, or equivalent

courses.name: Health Economics - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Analyzes the economics of health care in the United States with particular attention paid to the role of government.  It examines the demand for health care and the structure and consequences of public and private health insurance; the supply of health care, including professional training, licensure, specialization and compensation, hospital competition and finance, and the determinants and consequences of technical change in medicine and health care reform.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 3251 or ECONOM 4351 and STAT 2500, or equivalent

courses.name: Economic Development
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 4360; cross-leveled with ECONOM 7360). The study of less-developed countries including problems of measuring economic growth, analysis of sources of economic growth, causes of changes in economic and structure, development and trade policies. The consequences of goals and assumptions for development policy are analyzed.

courses.name: Comparative Economic Systems
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4361). Study of capitalism, market socialism, and central planning.

courses.name: Law and Economics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM  7367l PUB_AF 7367). This course is a survey of economic analyses of American legal institutions.  Students will apply basic microeconomics, game theoretic and statistical concepts to the study of property, contracts, torts, the legal process, crime, and the judiciary.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 3251 or ECONOM 4351, and STAT 2500, or equivalent

courses.name: Law and Economics - Writing Intensive
courses.description: This course is a survey of economic analyses of American legal institutions.  Students will apply basic microeconomics, game theoretic and statistical concepts to the study of property, contracts, torts, the legal process, crime, and the judiciary.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 3251 or ECONOM 4351, and STAT 2500, or equivalent

courses.name: Quantitative Economics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7370). The aim of this course is to provide an introduction to the mathematical language of economic theory.  Topics include linear models, matrix algebra, rules of differentiation and comparative static analysis, optimization.

courses.name: Introductory Econometrics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7371). Study methods for quantitative analysis of economic data. Estimation techniques, tests of significance, prediction and forecasting reviewed with respect to problems presented by economic data and information demands of economic decision models.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 3251 or ECONOM 4351, and STAT 2500, or equivalent

courses.name: Structural Change in Economic History
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7384). Explores changes in the structure of the American economy from its earliest colonial beginnings. Structural change, an integral part of growth, is related to technical change, population growth and to the content and form of economic theory.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024 and ECONOM 1015, or ECONOM 1051

courses.name: Problems in Economics
courses.description: Development of a carefully considered research project under close supervision of a faculty member.  Credit arranged by instructor.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 4351, ECONOM 4371, and instructor's consent.  Not open to non-majors

courses.name: Dynamic Optimization and its Applications to the Natural Sciences and Economics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7775). Development of Calculus of Variations and Optimal Control Theory. Applications. Extensions to stochastic and robust control.

courses.name: Internship in Economics
courses.description: Internship experience for Economics majors.  40 hours of supervised internship work with approval of Director of Undergraduate Studies and academic advisor.  Graded on S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: C or higher in ECONOM 4351 and ECONOM 4371; Declared economics majors who have a minimum overall CUM  GPA of 2.75 and have junior or senior standing
courses.recommendation: Students must have completed at least 15 credit hours at MU

courses.name: Independent Study in Economics
courses.description: Individual work, with conferences adjusted to needs of student.

courses.name: Senior Seminar in Economics
courses.description: Seminar for graduating seniors who are majoring in economics. Multiple writing assignments will emphasize synthesis of theoretical, empirical, and institutional economics. Not open to non-majors.

courses.name: Supplemental Senior Seminar in Economics
courses.description: Content description is the same as ECONOM 4970.  Required for Economics honors students and double majors in Economics who take a capstone course in another major.  No credit for students who have completed ECONOM 4970.  Not open to non-majors. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Honors Thesis
courses.description: Not open to non-majors.  Capstone course required for Economics honors students.

courses.name: Topics in Economics - General
courses.description: Study in applied or theoretical economics.  Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Problems in Economics
courses.description: Individual study in Economics.

courses.name: Labor Economics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4311).  Surveys theoretical explanations of wage and employment determination in contemporary labor markets.

courses.name: Public Economics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4315). Analyzes economic effects of government expenditures, taxes and debt. Expenditure and taxation principles, tax reform, cost-benefit analysis, fiscal policy.

courses.name: History of Economic Thought
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4320). Origins of modern economic thought in the context of social and intellectual environment of the time in which they originated, their contribution to their period and to modern thought.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024 and ECONOM 1015 or ECONOM 1051H

courses.name: Economics of Regulation and Antitrust
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4322). Economic issues concerning the role of government regulation. The course examines the rationale for and effects of regulatory policies in public utilities, transportation, and communications industries.

courses.name: The International Monetary System
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4325). Study of macroeconomic and monetary relationships between the US and the world. Topics include balance of payments, foreign exchange rates, history of the international monetary system.

courses.name: Economics of International Trade
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4326). The microeconomic theory of international trade. Topics include comparative advantage, the theory of commercial policy, economic integration, trade with LDC's and the trade effects of economic growth.

courses.name: The Banking System and the Money Market
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4329) Organization of the money market; credit control procedures and aims, effect of bank expansion and contraction on money market and national income deregulation.

courses.name: Microeconomics for Managers
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4332). Microeconomic concepts presented at the intermediate level, graphic treatment with limited calculus, managerial issues presented at the MBA level.  (Not open to economics majors).
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024, MATH 1300; permission required for MBA program

courses.name: Introduction to Game Theory
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4340). An introduction to the theory of games, viewed as a set of tools used widely in economics to study situations in which decision-makers (consumers, firms, governments, etc.) interact. The course introduces the basic theory, emphasizing the concepts and their economic applications.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 3251 or ECONOM 7351 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Economics of Education
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4345). Economic theory is used to analyze the market for educational services and education policy. Topics include: human capital theory, cost and performance measures for public and private schools, market based approaches to school reform, school finance, higher education cost and access.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024, or ECONOM 1051H and ECONOM 4371 or equivalent

courses.name: Intermediate Microeconomics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4351). Theory of rational behavior in consumption, production, and pricing decisions of households and firms. Partial equilibria in product and factor markets under competition, monopoly, oligopoly and monopolistic competition. A brief introduction to general equilibrium and welfare economics is provided. Calculus is employed. No credit for students who have completed 3251.
courses.prerequisites: (ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024 or ECONOM 1051) and MATH 1400 or equivalent

courses.name: Intermediate Macroeconomics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4353). The study of the structure and performance of national economics. Topics include: long-term economic growth, aggregate economic fluctuations, unemployment, and inflation; consequences for national economies of being part of the global economic system; government policies and macroeconomic performance.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 1015 or ECONOM 1051 and MATH 1400 or equivalent

courses.name: Industrial Organization and Competitive Strategy
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4355). Analyzes the structure of industry, its impact on the operations of the firm and significance for public policy. The focus is on strategic interaction among firms with market power.  Topics include oligopoly, competition, collusion, price discrimination, product differentiation, advertising, entry and exit.

courses.name: Health Economics
courses.description: (same as PUB_AF 7357; cross-leveled with ECONOM 4357). Analyzes the economics of health care in the United States with particular attention paid to the role of government.  It examines the demand for health care and the structure and consequences of public and private health insurance; the supply of health care, including professional training, licensure, specialization and compensation, hospital competition and finance, and the determinants and consequences of technical change in medicine: and examination of recent proposals and initiatives for health care reform.

courses.name: Economic Development
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4360, PEA_ST 4360). The study of less-developed countries including problems of measuring economic growth, analysis of sources of economic growth, causes of changes in economic and structure, development and trade policies. The consequences of goals and assumptions for development policy are analyzed.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 3229 and ECONOM 3251 or ECONOM 4351.; graduate standing required

courses.name: Comparative Economic Systems
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4361). Study of capitalism, market socialism, and central planning.

courses.name: Law and Economics
courses.description: (same as PUB_AF 7367; cross-leveled with ECONOM 4367). This course is a survey of economic analyses of American legal institutions.  Students will apply basic microeconomic, game theoretic and statistical concepts to the study of property, contracts, torts, the legal process, crime and the judiciary.
courses.prerequisites: [ECONOM 4351 or ECONOM 3251, and STAT 2500, or equivalent

courses.name: Quantitative Economics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4370). The aim of this course is to provide an introduction to the mathematical language of economic theory.  Topics include linear models, matrix algebra, rules of differentiation and comparative static analysis, optimization.

courses.name: Introductory Econometrics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4371). Study methods for quantitative analysis of economic data. Estimating techniques, tests of significance, prediction and forecasting reviewed with respect to problems presented by economic data and information demands of economic decision models.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 3251 or ECONOM 4351 and STAT 2500 and MATH 1320 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Structural Change in Economic History
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4384). Explores changes in the structure of the American economy from its earliest colonial beginnings. Structural change, an integral part of growth, is related to technical change, population growth and to the content and form of economic theory.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024 and ECONOM 1015, or ECONOM 1051H or instructor's consent

courses.name: Dynamic Optimization and its Applications to the Natural Sciences and Economics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4775). Development of Calculus of Variations and Optimal Control Theory. Applications. Extensions to stochastic and robust control.

courses.name: Topics in Economics- General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Problems in Economics
courses.description: Graduate students may select topics for study and investigation subject to approval by supervising faculty.

courses.name: Research in Economics
courses.description: Thesis research for M.A. degree. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Game Theory
courses.description: Game theory is the study of strategic behavior by agents who perceive themselves as "large" relative to the market and who therefore consider the effect of their behavior on others. This course examines the rigorous theory of strategic interaction of rational agents. May be repeated for credit.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 4351 or equivalent; MATH 1320 or equivalent. . Graded on A-F basis only

courses.name: Mathematics for Economics
courses.description: The aim of this course is to cover essential mathematics used in economics. Topics include introductory linear algebra, multivariate calculus, comparative statics analysis, unconstrained optimization, and equality constrained optimization. May be repeated for credit.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 4351 or equivalent; MATH 1320 or equivalent. Graded on A-F basis only

courses.name: Research Workshop I
courses.description: Required course for economics MA students.  Combines instruction, student presentations, and seminar participation to introduce research methods and practice. A major research paper are required.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 8451, ECONOM 8453, and ECONOM 8472 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Microeconomic Theory
courses.description: MA-level course in microeconomic theory.  The course relies extensively on calculus to survey theories of:  rational behavior in consumption, production, and pricing decisions of households and firms; partial equilibria in product and factor markets under competition, monopoly, oligopoly and monopolistic competition; and general equilibrium and welfare.

courses.name: Macroeconomic Theory
courses.description: Basic models in macroeconomics will be covered with emphasis on assumptions and on how hypotheses can be tested.  Course is an introductory survey for students intending to develop ability for research in macroeconomics.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 4353 or equivalent; at least concurrent enrollment in ECONOM 8451.  Instructor's consent required for non graduate level students

courses.name: Dynamic Optimization
courses.description: Topics to be covered include calculus of variations, optimal control theory, dynamic programming in discrete time variables, and economic modeling. The Euless Equation, the Transversally Condition and the Bellman Equation will also be covered.

courses.name: Econometric Methods I
courses.description: Familiarizes students with fundamental techniques found and used in applied economic research. Topics include: ordinary least squares, generalized least square, instrumental variables, maximum likelihood estimation, and generalized methods of moments.

courses.name: Applied Econometrics
courses.description: Topics include: nonlinear least squares, numerical optimization, maximum likelihood and basic panel data and time series methods.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 7371 and MATH 7140 or equivalent, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Topics in Economics
courses.description: Selected current topics in economics.

courses.name: Problems in Economics
courses.description: Graduate students may select topics for study and investigation subject to approval by supervising faculty.

courses.name: Research in Economics
courses.description: Thesis research for Ph.D. degree. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Labor Economics I
courses.description: Analysis of the determination of wages and employment and the relation of trade unionism to the economy.

courses.name: Advanced Labor Economics II
courses.description: Applications of contemporary analytical techniques to labor market topics chosen by the instructor.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 9411 and ECONOM 9452 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Research Workshop II
courses.description: Introduces doctoral students to practices of preparing scholarly economic research by moving through the process of selecting a topic, identifying relevant literature, and communicating results.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 9452, ECONOM 9454 and ECONOM 9474; PhD standing

courses.name: Advanced Public Economics I
courses.description: Tax incidence and optimal taxation in static economies and issues of taxation in dynamic economies.

courses.name: Advanced Public Economics II
courses.description: Macroeconomic issues of government finance. Theoretical and empirical analysis of Ricardian equivalence.

courses.name: International Trade
courses.description: Pure theory of international trade and commercial policy.

courses.name: Topics in International Trade
courses.description: The course will cover recent research in International Trade and important issues related to the impact of trade on economic growth and development.  Topics include the relationship between trade and growth, the impact of international trade on firms, households and economic growth.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Money and Banking
courses.description: The working and structure of institutional arrangements, welfare aspects of structural policies, operation of money and credit markets, and behavior of returns on assets.

courses.name: Central Banking Policies
courses.description: Examines central banking procedures, policies and the role they play in maintaining economic stability. Special attention to connection of Federal Reserve System with money and capital markets.

courses.name: Advanced Empirical Methods
courses.description: Empirical and modeling techniques for evaluation of microeconomic policy questions.
courses.recommendation: Concurrent enrollment in ECONOM 8473 or ECONOM 9473

courses.name: Topics in Microeconomic Policy Analysis
courses.description: (same as PUB_AF 9447). Applies the methods and techniques of microeconomics and to specific timely policy questions.  Taught by applied-microeconomics faculty and focuses on current topics in labor economics, public economics, the economics of education, health economics, and other applied areas of microeconomics.
courses.recommendation: Concurrent enrollment in ECONOM 8473 or ECONOM 9473

courses.name: Advanced Microeconomic Theory I
courses.description: The theory of rational behavior and partial equilibrium in markets.  Topics include consumer behavior, theory of the firm, decisions making under uncertainty, perfect competition, monopoly and monopsony, and imperfect competition.  Graded on A/F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 9451 or instructor's consent; PhD standing

courses.name: Advanced Microeconomic Theory II
courses.description: Survey of equilibrium theory and market failures in economics. Topics include the structure and modeling of games, and cooperative and non-cooperative equilibrium concepts.

courses.name: Advanced Macroeconomic Theory I
courses.description: Aggregate models of life-cycle microfoundations, of macroeconomics fluctuations and growth.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Macroeconomic Theory II
courses.description: Analyzes topics in income analysis, including capital theory and economic dynamics.

courses.name: Monopoly and Competition
courses.description: A survey of the theoretical and empirical literature on the organization of industries. Includes study of monopolized markets, competitive markets, and strategic interaction among firms in imperfectly competitive markets. Both the rationale and practice of anti-trust policy are studied.
courses.prerequisites: ECONOM 9452 and ECONOM 9471 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Computational Economics
courses.description: Covers numerical and computational methods to solve economic models at the research frontier. Emphasis is on practical applications to prepare students for independent research. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Development Economics
courses.description: Theories of economic development critically examined. Sources and consequences of growth processes analyzed in context of economic theory and historical occurrence.

courses.name: Advanced Game Theory
courses.description: Presents core concepts in game theory and illustrates their uses with a range of applications.

courses.name: Econometric Theory I
courses.description: Analysis of linear regression models from an advanced statistical perspective.

courses.name: Econometric Theory II
courses.description: Analysis of nonlinear regression models and other essential econometric tools not covered in ECONOM 9472 from an advanced statistical perspective.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Econometrics I
courses.description: Equips students with some essential tools for conducting publishable econometric research. Topics at the discretion of the instructor - typically time series analysis.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Econometrics II
courses.description: Equips students with some essential tools for conducting publishable econometric research.  Topics at the discretion of the instructor - typically microeconometrics.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Econometrics III
courses.description: Equips students with some essential tools for conducting publishable econometric research. Topics at the discretion of the instructor - typically the second semester of a two-semester time series sequence beginning with ECONOM 9474 or a two-semester microeconometrics sequence beginning with ECONOM 9476.

courses.name: Independent Readings for Ph.D. Comprehensive Examinations
courses.description: Independent Readings for Ph.D. Comprehensive Exam.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Economic History
courses.description: Techniques of the new economic history are explored in the context of European economic development.
